Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Collaborative Research: Testing the paradigms of the colloidal glass: Novel concentration jump experiments and large scale computer modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1506072 McKenna, Gregory B.
CBET - 1506079 Zia, Roseanna N.

Colloids are dispersions of particles in a liquid, such as water, and the particles are so small that they do not separate for very long times. The materials are widely used in commercial products such as paints and inks. They are also believed to be a good model materials for glasses. The present work is a collaborative study that combines experiment and large scale computer simulations that will provide novel scientific understanding of the behavior of colloidal glasses and comparisons will be made with knowledge from the literature concerning molecular glasses in similar conditions. Graduate and high school students will participate in the research activities at both PIs' institutions.

Understanding dynamical arrest in complex matter is a great challenge in soft matter science. Most study of colloidal systems near jamming assumes parity with corresponding behavior in molecular glasses. Yet, recent studies reveal non-equilibrium responses in colloids that differ qualitatively from glassy dynamics as monitored via the Kovacs signatures, viz., the intrinsic isotherm, the asymmetry of approach, and the memory effect. The proposed study will illuminate the structural underpinnings of such differences through a novel combination of experiment and dynamic simulation. The structure and dynamics will be determined in experiments analogous to the Kovacs experiments for molecular glass-forming systems. Here stimulus-responsive particles will change diameter at constant number density to create concentration-jump conditions to mimic the temperature-jumps of the Kovacs signature experiments. Concurrent simulations will effect similar conditions in silico. Experiment and simulation will inform and validate each other and the joint interrogation of the colloid dynamics near to the jamming transition will potentially create a transformative understanding of arrested states in soft matter. In a broader sense, this is a collaboration of two very different PIs. One is an expert in the experimental physics of molecular glasses, especially aging. The other is an expert in large scale computer simulation, with emphasis on colloidal systems. The result provides unique cross-disciplinary training to graduate students in both computational and experimental physics, deepening their knowledge of the fundamentals of dynamics and aging of molecular and colloidal glasses. Further, women and under-represented minorities will play a central role as undergraduate and graduate researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many molecular liquids transition from a liquid to a crystalline state upon cooling but if cooling is sufficiently rapid, the material can undergo a glass transition, whereby it solidifies without crystallization, forming a glass in which the amorphous structure is retained but the dynamics become extremely slow. The detailed mechanism of the glass transition has been identified as one of the grand challenges in condensed-matter science for at least two decades, but is still poorly understood.  Meanwhile, colloids -- microscopically small particles suspended in a liquid -- form an excellent model system for studying the behavior of molecular systems, partly because colloids are big enough to see visually with microscopes, and partly because their phase transitions are observably slow.  Thus the colloidal glass transition is studied in order to shed light on the molecular glass transition.  In addition, glassy arrest of the colloidal fluid-crystal transition is of direct industrial and biological interest, e.g. drying of industrial coatings or ink-jet droplets; emergent reports of glassy colloidal states in biological cells dramatically expands its relevance. The colloidal glass transition has been, since the 1980s, identified as a total suppression of the formation of crystalline structure occurring at the volume fraction where particle dynamics vanish. Understanding this so-called colloidal glass transition has the potential to shed light on the molecular glass transition.  Prior to our work, the glass transition "point" was argued to be divergent (a requirement for 2ndorder thermodynamic transitions) at a volume fraction obtained by extrapolation. Difficulty obtaining dynamical data above 59% volume fraction justified assumptions of divergence. Meanwhile, mechanistic understanding of the glass transition remained murky, partly because of a little-recognized fact that experimental approaches to entering the glassy state all required some sort of flow(tumbling or shear) that can seed crystals.  We constructed a novel computational model to quench from a liquid into the glass by increasing particle size at fixed volume fraction, avoiding flow. Our experimental collaborator (Gregory B. McKenna Lab, Texas Tech University) conducted companion experiments.  We systematically studied particle dynamics following quenching and found that structural relaxation deepens but does not arrest particle dynamics, even close to maximum packing.  We utilize dynamic simulations and experiments to quench a colloidal liquid into the putative glass by triggering a sudden increase in particle size and thus volume fraction, avoiding flow to minimize influence on particle dynamics. We are able to traverse the quench region spanning volume fractions from 0.56 to 0.63 and find that relaxation dynamics do not diverge in this region. A decoupling of physical and wave-space measurements of relaxation reveals the mechanistic origin of this behavior: The glass transition commences without diverging dynamics because a secondary long-time in-cage diffusive regime emerges, where high density permits sampling of many configurations with localized motion.
